title-group.article-title: Management of interstitial pregnancy – a case managed with ultrasound guidance and a review of literature

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, Wrexham Maelor Hospital, Wrexham, Clwyd, UK
2Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, Ysbyty Gwynedd Hospital, Bangor, Gwynedd, UK

permissions.copyright-statement: © The British Medical Ultrasound Society 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Interstitial pregnancy is a rare form of ectopic pregnancy. Interstitial pregnancy refers to an ectopic pregnancy implanted in the interstitial portion of the tube. This is the segment of Fallopian tube traversing the muscular wall of the uterus, beginning at the tubal ostium and proceeding superiorly and laterally away from the uterine cavity to join the isthmic portion of the tube arising from the fundus. The interstitial portion, being a relatively thicker portion of the tube, has a greater capacity to expand before rupture takes place. Therefore, such pregnancies may present late and rupture can result in life-threatening haemorrhage, particularly because of the high vascularity of this region. Diagnosis is difficult and treatment has not been standardized. A high index of suspicion is required to diagnose this type of pregnancy. Access to high-resolution transvaginal ultrasonography and highly sensitive quantitative β-hCG assays has increased early detection and appropriate management. A wide array of treatment methods have been tried for the management of this condition. The optimum therapeutic option depends on variables related to each individual case.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Interstitial pregnancy is a rare form of tubal ectopic pregnancy, with an incidence estimated at 2.4% of all ectopic pregnancies.1 The overall incidence of ectopic pregnancy has remained static in recent years, although some studies mention an increasing incidence, attributable to an increase in the incidence of pelvic inflammatory disease. The incidence of interstitial pregnancy is rising, probably because of increase in the rate of diagnosis, aided by high-resolution ultrasound technology. Traditional treatment with laparotomy, hysterectomy, or cornual wedge resection is associated with high morbidity and detrimental effects on future fertility. A diverse array of alternative treatments has been introduced over the last three decades, with the common goal of achieving a minimally invasive, standardized management strategy.

We report a case of successful treatment of an interstitial pregnancy. In this case, an initial unsuccessful systemic injection of methotrexate was followed by ultrasound-guided aspiration of the gestational sac and local injection of methotrexate into the sac.

sec.title: Case report
sec.p: A 29-year-old second gravida presented at six weeks gestation with lower abdominal pain, which was progressively increasing in intensity. There was no history of bleeding per vaginum. She was clinically stable. She had an uneventful full-term vaginal delivery of a healthy infant, eight years ago.

Following a positive urinary pregnancy test on admission, serum β-hCG level was found to be 4006 IU/L. The possibility of a live interstitial pregnancy was noted on a transvaginal ultrasound (TVUS) scan the next day (see Figure 1). Further serum β-hCG estimation showed a drop to 2118 IU/L after 48 hours. This fall of hCG level suggested the possibility of non-viability of the pregnancy. However, a repeat test in 48 hours showed a rise to 9426 IU/L. A diagnostic laparoscopy was performed, which confirmed the presence of interstitial pregnancy (see Figure 2). Figure 1
Transvaginal scan showing transverse section through uterine fundus on the right with adjacent interstitial pregnancy. The central echogenic endometrial thickening is clearly visible within the uterine fundus, identified by a series of four arrows. The interstitial pregnancy is shown by a single arrow pointing downwards
Figure 2
Shows laparoscopic view of right sided interstitial pregnancy distending the cornual region of uterus

Non-invasive management was undertaken with administration of 80 mg methotrexate injection intramuscularly. Serum β-hCG on the fourth day after methotrexate injection was found to have risen to 17210 IU/L. A repeat ultrasound scan showed persistence of a live interstitial pregnancy of approximately six weeks and three days’ gestation.

Options for further management were discussed with the patient, namely, ultrasound-guided aspiration of the sac with local injection of methotrexate, or excision of uterine cornu by the laparoscopic method or through laparotomy if required. The patient opted for local injection of methotrexate.

The procedure was performed under general anaesthesia. A transvaginal scan confirmed a live pregnancy in the interstitial portion of the Fallopian tube on the right side. The gestation sac contents were aspirated through a 19.5 G Bard 28 cm needle, introduced vaginally under ultrasound guidance (Figure 3). 25 mg methotrexate was subsequently injected into the sac. No fetal heart beat was seen at the conclusion of this procedure. The patient remained haemodynamically stable and was discharged home on the second post-operative day. Figure 3
Transverse section through uterine fundus and interstitial ectopic shows ultrasound guided needle introduced inside the gestational sac. The gestational sac shows echogenicity due to haemorrhage and clots following an attempt to aspirate. The echo of the needle is demonstrated by black arrows

The serum β-hCG level, four days after the local methotrexate injection, had dropped to 11,158 IU/L. The serum level dropped further to 6372 IU/L on the seventh day. The patient was followed up with serial β-hCG levels and TVUS. Serum β-hCG levels dropped to <50 IU/L five weeks after the procedure (Chart 1). Chart 1
Fall of β-hCG over time

A scan seven weeks after the procedure confirmed progressive resolution of the interstitial pregnancy, with resumption of normal menstrual periods. An avascular mixed echo area was visualized on ultrasound at this stage. The patient was discharged from our care with instructions to report early in the next pregnancy to rule out recurrence of ectopic pregnancy.

sec.title: Review of the literature on management of interstitial pregnancy
Methods
sec.p: We identified relevant studies on the management of interstitial pregnancy by a computer search of PubMed and Medline databases from 1980 to 2012, limited to publications in English. Searches of electronic medical databases were carried out using MeSH terminologies: interstitial pregnancy, current diagnosis and management of interstitial pregnancy, methotrexate and laparoscopy.

sec.title: Definition
sec.p:
Definition of interstitial pregnancy is plagued with a variety of interpretation. It is sometimes mistakenly referred to as cornual pregnancy and frequently confused with angular pregnancy. Differentiation among these three conditions is clinically important because their behaviour, management and outcomes are different. Angular pregnancy occurs when an embryo implants in the lateral angle of the uterine cavity, medial to the internal ostium of the fallopian tube (Figure 4).2,3 Angular pregnancies lead to asymmetric and symptomatic enlargement of the uterus and end in miscarriage in 38.5% of cases. Persistent pain or recurrent vaginal bleeding during pregnancy, retention of placenta during the third stage of labour and rarely, uterine rupture are among the potential complications of angular pregnancy, although the symptoms resolve and a normal pregnancy may follow in a significant number of women.2 Figure 4
Diagram showing possible locations of ectopic gestation (1–5) and the relevant anatomical structure of female genital tract. 1 – ampullary; 2 – ovarian; 3 – isthmic; 4 – interstitial; 5 – angular; 6 – ovarian ligament; 7 – round ligament; 8 – ovary; 9 – vagina; 10 – uterine cavity

Interstitial pregnancy is an ectopic pregnancy that is implanted in the interstitial portion of the fallopian tube, which is defined as the tubal segment traversing the muscular wall of the uterus. This segment originates at the tubal ostium and follows a tortuous course superiorly and laterally away from the uterine cavity to the point at which the isthmic portion of the tube arises from the uterine fundus. The interstitial portion of the tube averages 0.7 mm in diameter and 1–2 cm in length and has a relatively greater capacity to expand before rupture, than the other distal portions of the tube. Therefore, interstitial pregnancy may remain asymptomatic until early second trimester of pregnancy in rare cases and rupture can lead to life-threatening haemorrhage because of the rich vascular anastomosis of the uterine and the ovarian arteries in this region of the uterus and tube.2 This general belief about late rupture of interstitial pregnancy has been disputed, however, by Tulandi and Al-Jaroudi,4 who reported the results of an Interstitial Pregnancy Registry sponsored by the Society of Reproductive Surgeons. In their series of 32 cases of interstitial pregnancy, rupture occurred relatively early in pregnancy.
A cornual pregnancy refers to pregnancy in a horn of a bicornuate uterus.2,5 The picture is somewhat confused by interchangeable use of the terms ‘cornual’ pregnancy and ‘angular’ pregnancy.

Often, the difference between an interstitial pregnancy and an angular pregnancy is subtle. In addition, it may be easy to confuse an angular pregnancy with a pregnancy in a septated or bicornuate uterus. Because ultrasound cannot always confirm the position of the pregnancy, laparoscopy may be required to confirm the diagnosis.3

sec.title: Incidence
sec.p: Interstitial pregnancies account for only 2–4% of tubal pregnancies, or approximately one in 2500–5000 live births.3 The mortality rate is as high as 2.5%, a rate that is seven times greater than that of ectopic pregnancies in general.2,4

sec.title: Aetiology
sec.p: The exact pathogenesis of this type of gestation is unknown; however, it is thought to be associated with abnormal transportation of the fertilized ovum within the fallopian tube.6

sec.title: Risk factors
sec.p: Risk factors for interstitial pregnancy are similar to those for ectopic pregnancy that is located in the more distal tube.4,7 The most common risk factors were tubal damage from previous ectopic pregnancy, previous ipsilateral or bilateral salpingectomy, conception after in vitro fertilization and history of sexually transmitted disease.4 Other risk factors include history of pelvic inflammatory disease, intrauterine device and previous tubal surgery. In particular, patients with ipsilateral salpingectomy or cornual reanastomosis appear to have specific risk for interstitial pregnancies.6 There is therefore no single risk factor that clearly differentiates patients with an interstitial pregnancy from others.

sec.title: Clinical
sec.p: The most common symptoms of interstitial pregnancy are abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding in the first trimester of pregnancy. Since the introduction of high-resolution transvaginal ultrasonography and the highly sensitive quantitative β-hCG assays, early and accurate diagnosis has become possible.5,8 The higher the index of suspicion for interstitial pregnancy, the earlier the diagnosis is made.8

sec.title: TVUS
sec.p: TVUS is the primary method of diagnosis for interstitial pregnancies before surgery. Interstitial pregnancies are often discovered in asymptomatic patients during TVUS that is performed in the first trimester. One case series of 27 interstitial pregnancies (also referred to synonymously as cornual pregnancy in this study) reported that TVUS was diagnostic of interstitial pregnancy in 15 of the 27 patients (56%) at a mean gestational age of 8.2 weeks.8 In another case series, TVUS established the diagnosis in 23 of 32 patients (71%) at a mean gestational age of 6.9 weeks.4

Timor-Tritsch et al.9 described sonographic criteria for interstitial pregnancy. These criteria are (1) an empty uterine cavity, (2) a chorionic sac seen separately and more than 1 cm from the most lateral edge of the uterine cavity and (3) a thin myometrial layer surrounding the chorionic sac. These parameters were relatively specific (88% to 93%), but lacked high sensitivity (only about 40%) for the diagnosis of interstitial pregnancy.

Other investigators have described an “interstitial line sign.” This sign refers to the visualization of an echogenic line extending from the endometrial cavity into the cornual region and abutting the interstitial mass or gestational sac. Ackerman et al.10 reported that the “interstitial line sign” was 80% sensitive and 98% specific for the diagnosis of interstitial pregnancy.

sec.title: Magnetic resonance imaging
sec.p: Although TVUS with colour-flow mapping is the first choice in the early diagnosis of interstitial pregnancy, magnetic resonance imaging may be used if ultrasound is inconclusive in ruling out the diagnosis of interstitial pregnancy, and particularly, in differentiating it from an angular or intrauterine pregnancy.11,12

sec.title: Surgical diagnosis
sec.p: Many interstitial pregnancies are not diagnosed before surgery, either because ultrasonography was not performed in the first trimester, or the pregnancy was mistaken for other types of ectopic pregnancy. In one series, only 23 of 32 patients (71%) were diagnosed before surgery.4 In another series, only 56% of 27 patients were diagnosed before surgery.8

sec.title: Management
sec.p: Management is broadly divided into nonsurgical and surgical methods.

sec.title: Nonsurgical treatment
sec.p:

sec.title: Expectant management
sec.p: Expectant management is usually done in early pregnancies with low or declining serum β-hCG levels. We found 13 patients who had expectant management of interstitial pregnancy.9,13–16 It was successful in 11 patients and two patients required additional treatments. Cassik et al.16 reported two patients who required laparotomy.

The main attraction of expectant management is the avoidance of side effects associated with medical treatment, as well as eliminating the surgical and anaesthetic risks. Expectant management may be an appropriate option in some women with failing interstitial pregnancies. Close follow-up evaluation with serum β-hCG levels and TVUS is necessary, as there is a risk of rupture.

sec.title: Systemic methotrexate
sec.p: This is the most widely reported nonsurgical treatment for interstitial pregnancies. Various regimens of administering the drug have been reported. Close follow-up and evaluation is necessary as there is a risk of subsequent rupture. This management may fail if there is a live interstitial pregnancy. However, success rates are high.
We found that systemic management with methotrexate administered as an intravenous17 or intramuscular injection18–30 was successful in 55 out of 66 patients.

Additional treatment with laparoscopy was required in eight patients. Local methotrexate was used in three patients. Local methotrexate injection was combined with bilateral uterine artery embolization in two patients.31 In addition to local methotrexate, transcervical aspiration was also done in one patient.32 Local etoposide was used in one patient.33 Systemic Actinomycin D was used successfully in one patient.34

sec.title: Local injection
sec.p: The best-studied agent for local injection is methotrexate, with success rates as high as 91% in one series5 and 100% in another series.28

Local injections of methotrexate have been used to treat both viable and non-viable interstitial pregnancies. Data reported in the literature (Table 1) suggest the superiority of local therapy in both the safety aspect and success rates. In general, a likely explanation for the increased effectiveness of local injections is a higher concentration of the therapeutic agent achieved in the target tissue.41

Absorption of methotrexate into the circulation occurs after both local and systemic administration.41 A lower dose of methotrexate is used locally, leading to lower systemic levels and therefore fewer side effects. We found 41 patients treated with local methotrexate.9,16,20,25,28,29,36–38 Only two patients required additional treatment with laparotomies.

The major disadvantages of medical treatment are the need for prolonged follow up and uncertainty about the effects on future fertility and pregnancies. The reports suggest that once the serum β-hCG levels have begun to decline, the risk of rupture is low. It is therefore safe to manage cases of interstitial pregnancy in an outpatient setting, provided there is a continuous decline in serum β-hCG levels.28

Several authors have reported successful treatment of interstitial pregnancies with local injection of methotrexate or other cytotoxic drugs directly into the pregnancy, using laparoscopic35 ultrasonographic,8,25,29 or hysteroscopic guidance.36

Seven patients were treated with local potassium chloride injection, none of whom required additional treatment. Potassium chloride 20% (KCl) is the preferred local agent for interstitial pregnancies that are associated with a viable intrauterine pregnancy (heterotopic pregnancy).9,13,25,37,39

Other chemotherapeutic agents such as etoposide33 have been used successfully when injected directly into interstitial pregnancies. There was one series of five heterotopic pregnancies with live interstitial pregnancies. They were all successfully treated with transvaginal scan guided aspiration of interstitial pregnancy and instillation of hyperosmolar glucose.42
These approaches remain experimental until more information can be obtained regarding safety and efficacy.

sec.title: Combined systemic and local treatment
sec.p: Seven patients had combined treatment with systemic methotrexate and local methotrexate.19,25,40 It was successful in four of these patients; however, it failed in three patients, who required a laparotomy.

sec.title: Selective uterine artery embolization
sec.p: Selective uterine artery embolization has been successfully performed in recent years.31 Although uterine artery embolization offers a non-surgical option for therapy, like many of the reported treatments for interstitial pregnancy, it remains experimental until more information can be obtained regarding safety and efficacy.

sec.title: Surgical treatment
sec.p: When rupture of an interstitial pregnancy is suspected, expedient surgical treatment is the most appropriate option. Unfortunately, in many cases in which uterine rupture has occurred or a very large interstitial pregnancy is present, a hysterectomy may be required. Hysterectomy remains the treatment of choice for pregnancies advanced to such a stage that repair of the cornu would be technically difficult and medically hazardous.3

Several surgical approaches have been reported for the treatment of interstitial pregnancies. Earlier diagnosis, particularly before rupture, has enabled the development of more conservative surgical approaches, many of which avoid laparotomy. With the increasing availability of necessary equipment and expertise, laparoscopic treatment of intact and even ruptured interstitial pregnancies is becoming more common.

Laparoscopic treatment offers several advantages over laparotomy that include shorter hospital stay, faster return to normal activities and decreased healthcare cost.43 Several different laparoscopic techniques have been introduced over the last two decades. These include laparoscopic cornuostomy,29,44 laparoscopic salpingotomy44 and laparoscopic cornual resection. Moawad et al.2 reported a cumulative success rate of 85% with the use of various laparoscopic techniques in an excellent review of literature.

However, laparotomy remains the preferred treatment approach if laparoscopic expertise is not available or when expeditious laparoscopy cannot be achieved in the patient whose condition is hemodynamically unstable.

sec.title: Laparoscopy and hysteroscopy
sec.p: Cai et al.45 reported a prospective study of 22 patients in whom 15 were treated with laparoscopy. Five out of seven were treated with hysteroscopy and suction using a 8 F paediatric catheter. Two cases required further treatment with laparoscopy and laparotomy secondary to cornual uterine perforation.

sec.title: Hysterectomy
sec.p: Although hysterectomy was previously used to treat 50% of all interstitial pregnancies, the morbidity and permanent sterilization that was associated with this procedure make its use best limited only to women who had uncontrollable haemorrhage or very large interstitial pregnancies or who do not desire future fertility and who have other uterine pathologic diseases that will require hysterectomy for treatment (e.g. large symptomatic fibroids or adenomyosis).3 Hysterectomy was the most common treatment in the past, but now it is the treatment of last resort.

sec.title: Follow up
sec.p: Usually patients are followed up with serial TVUS and serial β-hCG assays until resolution.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Diagnosis and treatment of interstitial pregnancy is not straightforward. Individualization of care is necessary, depending upon various factors related to each case. It is obvious that many different methods of treatment have been tried by various authors, each method having its own advantages and disadvantages. Ultrasound-guided local injection of methotrexate is one of the most conservative methods of treatment, which preserves the fallopian tube and causes least damage to surrounding structures. However, this method needs expert skills in ultrasound-guided needle introduction and optimum circumstances to ensure adequate follow-up of the patient.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: Sonographers at our hospital for their initial ultrasound scan and diagnosis. All staff at John Spalding Library at Wrexham Medical Institute for helping with the literature search and provision of the relevant articles for review.

sec.title: Competing interests
sec.p: The authors have no conflicts of interest to declare.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: None.

sec.title: Ethical approval
sec.p: Written consent was obtained from the patient for publication of the case details.

sec.p: BK

sec.title: Contributorship
sec.p: SB and AA searched the online resources and prepared the first draft of this article. BK personally managed the case, performed the ultrasound examination and recorded the images. The laparoscopic image was also taken by BK.
